newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: INTERVIEW-ACPC to review coffee trade, export plan.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW-ACPC to review coffee trade, export plan.

text.p: The world's top coffee producers will meet in London to review conditions in the market before deciding on their export programme, Ivory Coast Commodity Minister Guy-Alain Gauze said on Wednesday.
Gauze told Reuters in an interview in Singapore that the 14-member Association of Coffee Producing Countries (ACPC) would need to review the findings of its technical panel first.
"For the time being, (the meeting) is just to review the market and a review of our whole system," he said. "I can't say what we are going to do."
Industry sources in Jakarta have said the meeting in London might delay taking a decision over fresh export quotas to see how the coffee market performs.
Coffee prices in New York and London have staged a blistering rally over fears of tight supplies.

London robusta futures rose four percent in the morning session on Wednesday with the benchmark July contract hitting a new one-year peak of US$1,885 a tonne. Prices settled in morning trade $55 up at $1,872.
Gauze, who is chairman of the InterAfrican Coffee Organisation (IACO), declined to say what kind of new export scheme the ACPC may consider.
The head of the International Coffee Organization (ICO), Celsius Lodder, said on Wednesday that sharp falls in reserves in consumer countries will allow growers to dictate the pace of coffee prices.
Gauze said world demand of coffee is growing quickly while supplies remained extremely tight.
"There is no more coffee in the producer countries. We are really facing problems with production," he said. --Singapore Newsroom (65-8703305)
